SPEECH.PARA: The other major facet of this Bill relates to the fact that the TPA may be permitted to construct new pipelines without the requirement for specific legislative approval.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you get around that one?

—That one does bother me, although not for the reasons Senator Durack may think. It bothers me because I feel that in general in Australia we do not have enough control over the potentially environmentally damaging projects which come up so often. I feel that we should have more avenues for examining environmental impact. We should have more hearing procedures; we should have more good, solid environmental impact statements, not the impact statements compiled by the developers, as is the case with the woodchip industry. We should have environmental impact statements compiled impartially by the Government itself. Such impact statements should be acted on impartially by the Government, with hearing procedures and legal access to the courts by interested parties so that we can in fact monitor environmental problems in the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the other thing that worries me about the Australian setup is the fact that the States have so much power in environmental and other areas. I think it is time that Australia faced the fact that it is a country and therefore needs to develop strong Federal controls. That, of course, is another matter. I am concerned about the removal of approval from the Parliament in this matter. The Parliament's record is not very good in relation to environmental situations in any event. For the purposes of this pipeline I feel that probably this Bill is a logical step.

As Senator Durack noted, the Pipeline Authority was established in 1974 by Rex Connor. This pipeline carries gas from Moomba in South Australia to Sydney. It will now have minor branch lines. The AGL purchases its gas from Santos Ltd and pays the pipeline on a volume basis for the cartage of gas, which the Australian Gas Light Co. markets in Sydney. The volume of gas put through the pipeline has not been as high as was anticipated in 1974. As a conse- quence the TPA has not received enough revenue to cover its costs. Of course, this is the main consideration in the Bill.

This raises two questions. Firstly, why was the volume of gas to be put through the pipeline overestimated? Secondly, was the actual pricing schedule done with a view to the future? In the first place I think that energy experts in Australia, in fact all around the world, have tended to overestimate the amount of energy required in the future. We see an overcapacity of energy production in all States. I refer to electricity production and, in this specific case, an overestimation of the volume of gas required. Unfortunately this all stems from the idea that the earth's resources are infinite and that we will be using more and more of everything. Of course, this is false. This consumption cannot take place over any length of time. It is an attitude that engineers are now finding is untenable and, to their credit, they are changing their ideas. It is a common occurrence in our society that we overestimate the amounts of things that we will use in the future. We hope that there will be ever more substances to fulfil our needs. It is time we faced up to the fact that we live on an earth with finite resources and that we should sculpt or model our demands to meet our resources.

The deal between AGL and the TPA is one that will actually save-even Senator Durack has admitted this-at least $1 billion and perhaps $2 billion. A mistake was made in the past. I do not think anyone will argue that point. I think it is to the Government's credit that it now wants to rectify this mistake. If we do not rectify this mistake the $59m which is now owed by the Pipeline Authority will mushroom; it will balloon and get totally out of control. Hopefully, this Bill will keep the monetary expenditure under control, it will in fact pay off the pipeline, all TPA losses will be paid off by the year 2006, and the taxpayers of Australia will benefit. It is for those reasons that I and the Democrats support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Pipeline Authority Amendment Bill 1985. The Bill seeks to do three things: It seeks, firstly, to report upon an agreement on future haulage tariffs between the Australian Gas Light Co. and the Pipeline Authority; secondly, it seeks authority for a member of the Australian Gas Light Co. to sit on the Pipeline Authority Board; and, thirdly, it seeks to remove the necessity for the Authority to seek annual approval for particular works programs.

SPEECH.PARA: To understand the situation and to understand the Bill itself one must recognise that the Pipeline Authority was set up as a Commonwealth statutory authority in 1974 to be the only haulage contractor-it held the monopoly-for the pipeline that was to run from Moomba in central Australia to Sydney, with laterals and spurs. As it is a fact that, as previous speakers have said, the haulage tariff was calculated on false assumption-an overestimation-I believe of the order of some six or seven trillion cubic feet, of the gas traffic on the pipeline for the period. In other words, the AGL Co. found that it was using only about half of the estimated traffic on the pipeline. As a result, the Auditor-General drew attention to the fact that a debt would be incurred. As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) said in his second reading speech, a long series of discussions were held over a period of some seven years or more.

I want to put the situation into perspective. It is true that there were protracted discussions, but any suggestion that there could have been any solution other than the Australian Gas Light Co. conceding to an increase in tariff is ludicrous. The fact of the matter is that the increase in the price of gas required to cover the increase in tariff and to wipe off the debt was minuscule in itself. Perhaps the Minister, when he replies in this debate, will indicate that that is so.

It is a simple fact that it was imperative for the Australian Gas Light Co. that the agreement be reopened at an early date, for a variety of reasons. All was not well in the hands of the Australian Gas Light Co. at all. It needed certain rearrangements of the agreement to suit its purposes. It needed compression points to be established progressively along the pipeline to boost the flow of gas. If this were to be allowed, the Government had a great argument for reopening the agreement to renegotiate prices. So it should not be considered that somehow or other a magic formula was reached. It was absolutely inevitable-it was only a matter of time and attrition before that became necessary. I say that as one who has had something to do with the progress of the pipeline and as one who knows something about the basis of the operation of the Australian Gas Light Co.

I should add that the AGL Co. is almost unique in Australia, being not just a limited company but a chartered company-a company that is formed by an Act of the Parliament and given a total monopoly, and rightly so, and which has an arrangement with the government of the day regarding pricing. It think that the former Bank of New South Wales was one of the few other chartered companies that existed in Australia. AGL was made a chartered company in the light of the experience in Victorian England, where there was no monopoly. In Pall Mall in particular, three or four pipelines which were operated by various gas companies ran down the road. In the absence of meters, an exhaust pump was put on at night times and bills were sent to those whose gaslights went out. That in itself did not appear to be a particularly successful way of running a gas company, so AGL was given a monopoly in Australia. Also, Queen Victoria had quaint idea about the habits of gas and insisted that gas pipes be put at a distance from the wall in case of fire. So we have a unique situation of a monopoly company-and rightly so-a company that, unless it takes methane gas from the Picton area, is entirely dependent on gas supplied, a company that needs compressors along the way and therefore has to have renegotiations of the agreement, and a company that needs new laterals built. It is not a question of a one way bargain. Inevitably the price would have been adjusted; it was a matter of doing that at a price which everybody knew, and which the government of the day knew, would not affect the consumer price index at all, or only marginally or insignificantly. That is the basis of the situation. The tragedy of this debate is that the agreement between the New South Wales Government and AGL and this Government is confidential and, therefore, we do not know what the agreement will be. For instance, I cannot make head nor tail of this statement by the Minister for Resources and Energy:
But a settlement has now been reached between the three parties under which AGL and the New South Wales Government can receive the benefits they seek . . .

I do not know what benefits the New South Wales Government sought and got. I would be very interested to know because, if one thing is certain, it is that if there is any question of the pipeline getting into private hands, the first nationaliser of the pipeline will be the Wran Government-if it is still in existence. It will want a monopoly control to use political interest to spread its laterals and spurs throughout New South Wales. So let us be perfectly clear on that situation. It was known all the time that the Australian Gas Light Co. would be given the right to acquire Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow gas companies, so that is not a bargain in terms of this agreement. I am not in any way knocking the agreement. I am delighted that it is reached, but I am reducing the agreement to a sensible size. It was inevitable; it had to happen; and it was only a matter of time. There is no question that there would have been an ultimate denial to the Australian Gas Light Co. of taking over Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow gas companies; no question that the New South Wales Government would resist the extension of gas pipelines to that central area of New South Wales. That is a ludicrous situation; there is no question of that. There is no question that this will be an essential part of the bargain. Therefore, when one puts it into perspective, one would have to say-and governments of the past decade have known it-that inevitably there would have been a readjustment of the tariff. It would have been a minor one. In any case the Pipeline Authority was making a profit on its other ventures. It was making a profit on Canberra. The long term effect of that has not been disclosed. I commend the fact that the agreement has been reached. I commend the fact that a lateral will be extended to Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow. That was sought in the past. No one could argue against that at all.

I now come to question No. 2-whether a representative of the Australian Gas Light Co. should be on the Pipeline Authority. Lest anyone should have any thought that I am criticising the AGL Co., I should say two things: I have the highest respect for it, and I should disclose an interest. Pre-war I worked for the Australian Gas Light Co. for a short period and therefore I have had some insight into the way it has worked in the past. It is a chartered company of high repute. It is a company that has a reputation, because of its nature, its price fixing and its stability, somewhat, like that of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co Ltd., whereby superannuation investments are major shareholdings of the whole company.

The Minister says there ought to be a representative of the Australian Gas Light Co. on the Pipeline Authority board. It is interesting that he has not said that therefore there ought to be a representative of the Pipeline Authority on the Australian Gas Light Company board. If the need to know of the workings of both and an intimate knowledge of both is such, I cannot see why there is a unilateral situation. There is a complete paradox in the Minister's speech because he said that for seven long years-it is a little longer than that because I fancy that I initiated, or at least spurred on, the discussions on the re-adjustment of the tariff-there has been a conflict between the company and the Pipeline Authority as to what ought to be the tariff, and there have been discussions on this. So it is recognised that there has been a major conflict of interest over the one link between the two; that is, that the haulage contractor fixes a tariff for the consumer. If that is so, how can the Government now say, there having been seven long years of a major conflict of interest, that one of its resolutions is to put the company which was in conflict with the Pipeline Authority into a position where it knows every intimate detail of what the Authority is doing? Also, the Pipeline Authority is the monopoly supplier and the major consumer of gas is being put on the board but not others. After all, the Wagga Wagga City Council is a consumer. What right has the AGL company to have intimate knowledge that another consumer does not have?

I ask the Australian Democrats to discuss this problem in an attempt to find a resolution. Perhaps they will tell the city councils of Wagga and Albury why they felt that this was a good idea at the time, having sat too close to Senator Gareth Evans over the years. No doubt as the years go by and other consumers come in, as we hope they will, we will have the strange situation of one consumer being allowed to know everything and other consumers not being allowed to know anything. That would be demonstrably a nonsense situation. It is no criticism on my part of the Australian Gas Light Co. I have to say that, as a former Minister for Resources and Energy, I resisted the approach for such a move because I believed that there ought to be a proper relationship between the supplier and the consumer and that they should be at a distance from each other and the true interests should be demonstrated. I believe this move is a fundamental mistake. As I say, I am not seeking to criticise the Australian Gas Light Co.

One of the fundamental principles that we have to keep in mind in looking at this whole situation is that unlike most other countries, where natural gas is supplied to the people through various sources, Australia exists on a single pipeline from Moomba to Sydney and laterally out through Young to Wagga. Therefore, we have a single pipeline with a single source of supply. I have urged, and I will continue to urge, that we should build an extra piece of pipeline some 90-odd kilometres or thereabouts between Wagga and Albury so that two gas fields, Bass Strait and Moomba, can be connected to the pipeline to overcome the enormous monopoly of the gas supplier, but nothing has been done on this. We have to be terribly careful because if we put a vested interest onto the Pipeline Authority and it thinks that if Bass Strait is linked to the New South Wales pipeline there might be some increase in the price of new gas, it will resist, on what it sees as sound business principles, something that could be of immense importance and interest nationally.

Fundamentally, we have the most delicate of circumstances. The fact that we are totally dependent on a single pipeline cannot be better demonstrated than by the fact that four or five years ago early one morning an enormous explosion occured some four kilometres out of the well-head at Moomba, resulting in a huge piece of the pipeline being blown up and a crater of enormous size. The only thing that saved Sydney consumers and the rest of the consumers from running out of gas was that there was four days of supply in the pipeline; there was a four-day period to patch it up. For many months afterwards there was an enormous concentration on how we could secure the pipeline, how we could make sure that no further difficulties occurred and how we could ensure that stress corrosion-which caused that explosion-would not happen in other parts of the pipeline. In this Senate many people have heard me tediously drawing attention to the need to secure an instrument to run along the pipeline, known quaintly as the intelligent pig, to ensure that the pipeline does not have such breakdowns. Indeed, I am delighted that the work that was started on this by the Fraser Government is now going to emerge with the securing of such an intelligent pig.

These decisions should be made in the national interest, not just in the interest of New South Wales. Let me give another illustration. South Australia has had a difficulty in its supply of gas. Its contract with Santos Ltd, from memory, is to expire in 1987. There are now considerable discussions and turmoil in respect of this. An interstate and a national decision to link Wagga and Albury to take gas from Bass Strait into New South Wales and reshunt gas coming to New South Wales back into South Australia would be one way to aid South Australia.

Such national decisions may involve stresses in terms of cost and stresses in terms of new development of compression and so on along the way. We should not have a consumer on the Pipeline Authority Board whose commercial interests might be diametrically opposed to decisions made. I would have expected the Government to come forward and tell us about the unique situation in Australia, a country dependent on one pipeline with one gas field feeding in; the danger of damage to the pipeline; the need to look nationally; the need to see whether we can link gas fields; the need to see whether we can help another State; the problems that arise from the size of the pipeline; the need for compressors and all these kinds of considerations, all of which have a national character and a very important character.

If there has been the complete conflict of interest for seven years which the Minister claimed in his second reading speech, the Government should tell us why that situation will be continued forever afterwards and why AGL should be invited aboard. I repeat in no subjective way that I have the highest regard for the reputation of the company and its directors. It is a company of great integrity. It has done a very great service to the people of Australia, but that is beside the point. It is a matter of principle and I ask the Australian Democrats, on the basis of that and on the basis of the second reading speech, to reconsider where they stand.

The argument is incontrovertible that, if there was a conflict in the past and if national interest is to be considered in the future, there should not be such a link. Equally, in the future, as in the past, we should persist in having the Pipeline Authority bring once a year to the parliament of the day its program for approval. We need to know whether it is a program that is in the best interests of the community or whether some commercial pressure has driven it a particular way. Is that not an important thing for us to know?

We ought to know, and the Australian Democrats ought to know, that environmental factors of enormous consequence can be involved. It is very interesting that the Democrats are not interested in this fact. They get terribly excited about woodchips and the Daintree but not this.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am interested in the Sydney-Newcastle pipeline.

—Yes, and that is what is called selective morality. Senator Mason is interested in the Newcastle pipeline. When I listen to the Democrats, I am sure that Benjamin Disraeli was right. He referred to the newspapers and said that they were like the courtesans of old-all power with no responsibility. I cannot think of a better description for the Democrats than that with which Disraeli provided us. The Democrats know about being selective, whether it is do a fiddle overnight on some tax policy or anything else--
—You voted for their silly amendment last night.

—I do not mind the Minister for Finance joining with the Government's allies. I wish the Government would declare that alliance and make the Democrats the fourth faction in the Australian Labor Party. I would then understand it and there would be greater honesty in this place. I repeat that the Democrats are showing selective morality on this. Let us ask ourselves why they think that woodchips, the Daintree and the Newcastle pipeline are important, but no other pipeline that is to be developed. Quite clearly, their attitude is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the Bill overall, we have to congratulate the Government, and I do without qualification, for bringing to an apparently good result-one hopes it is-an agreement which has been difficult for many years and for a number of Ministers to negotiate. Nevertheless, I say without churlishness: `Do not overstate that' because there was an inevitability about it. The Australian Gas Light Co. could not have continued for an indefinite period to seek things from the agreement without having to concede to a minor adjustment of price. So do not let us engage in any nonsense about that. Let us not think that it was entirely a tight packet. Let us not imagine that the packet depended on offering to the Australian Gas Light Co. the extension to Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow.

We have to be honest and say that the State Government had let the company know long before that that was what it wanted. I have said before quite clearly that it would be highly desirable for spur lines to go to those areas. There is nothing new in that. The great thing is that on the facts before us an agreement has been reached. I am very interested indeed to know what is meant by the interests of the New South Wales Government as referred to in the second reading speech. That has not been disclosed to us. I would be delighted to know whether the announcement of other financial arrangements, including the establishment of a financial pool that was announced recently between the Australian Gas Light Co. and the Wran Government, had anything to do with this. However, I say without churlishness that, thank goodness, we have got this far.

In summary, with regard to the two parties affected by this Bill, how can the Government say: `Look. We are reporting with immense relief and satisfaction the end of a massive conflict of interest involving the one overriding factor in the whole of the life of the pipeline, the one thing that exists as the function of the hauler, that is, the price, the tariff. We are reporting that there has been an immense conflict of interest but, don't worry, we will put the consumer who caused the conflict of interest on the Board and we will give that consumer all the details of everything we are doing so that that consumer, above any other consumer, be it the Wagga City Council or anybody else, will have a unique privilege'. I cannot understand, therefore, why the Government should not say: `Let us put a representative of the Pipeline Authority on the AGL Board, and then perhaps the Authority will have the advantage of knowing what the footwork of the Board is'. If it is interesting for one to know something about the footwork of the other, let it work both ways.

Then again, it is very quaint to say: `We do not need to bring before the Parliament the intentions of the Pipeline Authority to see whether there is a national interest involved, a State interest involved, or an environmental interest involved, or to see whether a conflict of interests is involved. After all, we do not need to do that at all, so let us take it out'.

I regret very much that in any discussion on pipelines this Government has not pointed out to the Australian people the fundamental problem of the single pipeline and the monopoly hauler. That is that we have, as I have said, one pipeline drawn from one gas field and with no subsidary feed-in should anything happen to that pipeline. It is almost unique in the world. Throughout the world the major safety factor for pipelines is that other fields around are brought in so that any kind of collapse or need for repairs can be offset.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is that one field is exhaustible.

—Yes. So I should have thought that I would have heard about some comtemplation of either linking Wagga and Albury or running a new pipeline from Bass Strait northward. I should have thought that we would have had, in any discussdion on the Pipeline Authority, some estimation of what the Bureau of Mineral Resources now thinks the Bass Strait gas field really is-a work program that the Fraser Government asked the BMR to do. It is absolutely essential to the knowledge of how a pipeline is operated. With those facts in mind, there are many questions to be answered. Why is it being done this way? Why was this story of the agreement overplayed? It is an agreement of which I thoroughly approve-although I make one qualification to that. None of us here can make the calculation, first, that the tariff now struck will provide the result in the year 2006. The Minister cannot say that in the journey from now until the year 2006 there will not need to be half a dozen changes in the tariff, and that there will not be a need to renegotiate the agreement altogether. So the presentation of the second reading speech leaves so much to be desired, because it suggests that by this action everything is solved. One thing that is put in perspective is that the journey looks better; but on the way will it be suggested that this will be the eternal price? Can anybody say that? Could anybody have predicted, for example, the way in which the ecomony has gone in the last three years? Could anybody have predicted the value of the Australian dollar, or the cost of wages, or the cost of inflation, or interest rates? How could anybody talk about these things? What is the effect of the upsurge of inflation and interest rates on the future cost of building pipelines? Of course one cannot predict for the future.

SPEECH.PARA: On balance, I commend the agreement of tariff. I take on board that the Government says that it is watertight. I commend this Government and the Government of New South Wales for it, and AGL; but I cannot go along with two things which are in direct conflict with everything else that is said in the second reading speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure for me to sit here and be subtly flattered by Senator Sir John Carrick.
—I did not think that what I had to say was flattering.

—It was flattery; I took it as flattery, anyway-taking a charitable view, as I do, of Senator Sir John Carrick-because obviously, like the rest of the Liberal Party, he is now beginning to regard the Australian Democrats as a sort of father figure, the Liberals feeling that they can rely on us to do things instead of doing them themselves. As Senator Sanders said earlier, this is something they have to look at. It is interesting that Senator Sir John Carrick raised, in what I thought was an excellent speech, some very good points which I would have thought the Liberal Party might have brought forward as amendments to the Pipeline Authority Amendment Bill. But no; we have again this situation of blank opposition to something, a sheer blocking technique, which I think is not at all good or sensible.
—What kind of amendment?
—The honourable senator mentioned three or four things in his speech. He should look at it in the Hansard.
—You name them.
—I will not do the honourable senator's work for him; he should do it himself.
—Senator Sir John Carrick was being constructive.

—I agree; he was being constructive. I am surprised that nothing has come forward from the resources and energy area of the Liberal Party which was rather more constructive and along the lines he had suggested. I have taken on board what he said. I am afraid that he tends to overestimate our ability to influence legislation. We do what we can for the community. As honourable senators will know, over the last few days we have done an enormous amount of good for the small business sector and for the farmers of this country by reducing the tax burden on them by $48m in a full year. We feel that that is a not inconsiderable achievement. It can be done-I think the Liberal Party ought to take note of this-by negotiation with government. Government is there to govern; it is elected to govern. Oppositions are there to oppose, one might say, but it is not quite as simplistic as that. I think oppositions are also there to assist government, if they can, towards a better and more reasonable way of doing things. As far as the community is concerned, it would rather see results than blank opposition, and I commend that thought to the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick made the point, which is quite spurious, that the Australian Democrats are interested only in woodchips. Of course we are interested in woodchips. It is a source of great concern to me that people in Japan would not allow their trees to be cut down but our trees can be cut down to provide paper bags and lavatory paper for the homes of Japan-at a net cost to the Australian taxpayer, of course. We do not sell the stuff at any profit; we lose money doing it. So naturally we are concerned about woodchips and rainforests.

I have also been concerned over the years with pipelines, and indeed that is what I now intend to turn to. I have a few things to say about pipelines. I will preface them by saying to Senator Sir John Carrick, just to meet his point, that on a number of occasions over the years I have been one of the few people who have pointed out consistently the appalling dangers which exist in the pipelines between Sydney and Newcastle, the incredible folly of putting together a pipeline to carry gas and, right alongside it, a pipeline to carry dangerous flammable fuels, even high octane aviation spirit. It seems to me to be a dreadful thing to have done and something we will pay for in New South Wales before we are through with it. I have said that again and again. No notice has been taken of it. I hope that there will be no appalling consequences. We have to imagine what the consequences could be if there were a bad break in that gas pipeline while the other pipeline was carrying liquid fuel.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you are going to give away parliamentary scrutiny of any further matters?
—No, parliamentary scrutiny was one of the things the Liberal Party might have brought forward as an amendment, now that I come to think of it.
—You may do it, I will commend you.

—As I have said, I will not do all the honourable senator's work for him. I will say that I have taken what he has said on board. The Democrats have discussed this question of whether or not it is desirable that the Australian Gas Light Co. should be on the Board. What this Parliament can do it can undo. I suggest that both the Liberal Party and the Australian Democrats keep an eye on this situation in the future. If we find that problems emerge it is a matter that can properly come to attention at that stage. I do not think we need to damn this arrangement out of hand before it begins. I think it is reasonable that we give it a fair chance. As I have said, if a problem arises it the future, I suggest to the honourable senator that it is possible for us to do something about it at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned that, while this Bill covers large costs of pipelines which would otherwise be met by government-that has to happen-it remains a fact that the costs will now presumably be passed on to the consumers of gas in the form of higher tariffs. I would like the Acting Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh) to give us some idea at some stage of what is involved there. How much higher will the tariffs be? What sort of deal has been done with the supplying company? What can people expect from this? If we are talking about costs to the Government, which might be $1 billion to $2 billion, I point out that money does not come from nowhere. Presumably that cost will be passed on to the consumer. If that is not correct or is an overly simplistic view, I would appreciate guidance from the Minister, and I think the public and the gas consumers of this country would also like guidance. On the whole the Democrats are not opposed to the user pay principle, but it ought not to be applied in total isolation from other considerations.

I have risen to speak in this debate mainly in the interests of the New South Wales cities of Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow, which Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned, they being his constituency, just as they are mine. After many years of negotiations those cities are to get a spur line which will provide them with natural gas, but at a cost agreed to be no more than 10 per cent higher than that paid for gas in capital cities. I think we can take it that means it will be 10 per cent higher because wherever something like that comes in honourable senators can be sure that government will exert the maximum it can to get what it can out of that agreement, and I do not argue with that.

I have discussed this matter in some depth with the mayors and town clerks of those three cities-Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow-and there can be no doubt at all that they have been at a very severe disadvantage and are still at a severe disadvantage because industry tends to follow gas now as a cheap fuel. It has been quite ridiculous to expect new ventures to start or old businesses to relocate in Bathurst or Orange when cheap gas is freely available in the western suburbs of Sydney, with all the other advantages of not being very far away from their source of sale. It is the old problem that this nation has of decentralisation, which is probably the most talked about and least done about issue in this country, and perhaps the most important we could consider.

We are one of the two or three most urbanised peoples in the world. That is a disgrace. We are a single nation occupying a whole continent. That is a privilege which we should deserve. If we consider those two facts together, I think we can see the most appalling consequences for the future. The logic of the future is that we ought not to be allowed to continue to occupy one continent when we simply abuse or do not use most of it. When one goes out into the western areas of New South Wales, one finds-I am sure Senator Sir John Carrick will agree-some of the most beautiful and productive country in the world. One could not find a better place for human beings to live. Yet we underuse it to an increasing degree as time passes rather than otherwise. This is not only stupid and uneconomic; it is dangerous. It is dangerous because societies in the future which have placed all of their emphasis on locating their populations in large cities may find, if there is any major disaster such as a nuclear war, that the bulk of their facilities and populations are wiped out.

That reminds me of a cogent point. I was in China some 10 years ago before I came to this Parliament. In the course of that visit I had occasion to meet the gentleman who was then the responsible member of the revolutionary committee for Shanghai. This is the grandiloquent terminology of the cultural revolution which some honourable senators will recognise. In effect, he was the mayor of Shanghai. He said that China was moving industry and people out of Shanghai as fast as it could in order to avoid the disgrace-this is how he put it-of Shanghai becoming the largest city in the world. I give him credit. The Chinese say, and I believe them, that because of the enormous decentralisation that they have achieved, initially through the commune system, they will be the major race which survives a nuclear war-which they, I might say, believe will come. They have got themselves in a position where they are decentralised. If there is a catastrophe they will indeed survive it in greater numbers than we will in Australia. I think that is something that we ought to bear in mind.

I ask the Minister, because I think there is a point to this, whether the Government will, for the very first time actually consider some concessions to this matter of decentralisation. It is not necessarily, plainly, for this $1 billion to $2 billion to be used for that purpose. The cost of providing the spur lines to the regional cities will represent only a fraction of this cost. What I am saying is that in light of the relatively small amounts involved when the weight of decentralisation is involved, will the Minister consider some mechanism by which Bathurst, Orange and Lithgow can obtain gas at a price at least competitive with the price for the western suburbs of Sydney; in other words, that the price is not 10 per cent higher but the same price. If that happens those three cities will thrive. There will be a growth of industry there and this will mean that we will have some chance of breaking the appalling problems of the western suburbs of Sydney. The social and economic problems there are due to the fact that it is choked, that it lacks facilities and that it is overcrowded. Anybody in his right mind would realise that it would be far better to have people living in Bathurst, Orange or Lithgow if there was industry there-if the jobs were available people would go there-than to have them cluttering up an increasingly choked urban mess like the western suburbs of Sydney. Does the Government not have the vision to see that this sort of thing is important to us in the future? If it has not got that vision then I suggest that it look at the situation. For heaven's sake, let it look beyond next pay day or the next public holiday in its policies and see whether something can be done for these three cities which have a tremendous potential. They are in one of the most fertile areas of Australia and obviously there is a reasonable, convenient and useful potential there for decentralisation, in both the economic and social sense, so that many thousands of Australians who would otherwise have grown up in Green Valley or somewhere like that can have a new and better life in a place where there is more room and more opportunity to live reasonably as decent human beings. It is not as if we lack room. We are not like Japan, after all, where everything in crowded. We have all the space. I am not talking about cities which are 1,000 miles away from Sydney. These cities are relatively close to Sydney and already have good communications with that city. They only need an extra little gesture from the Government-the equalisation of telephone charges and the equalisation of fuel costs-to have them boom and go ahead. Some cities, such as Dubbo and Wagga Wagga, are going ahead without that encouragement in spite of Government policy. Just think what could be done if Government policy were taken in the right direction. I urge the Government to take a broad view of that matter.

The second matter I wish to raise concerns something that was raised by both Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Jessop. They are concerned about single sources of supply. Senator Jessop made the point that the sources of supply of natural gas are exhaustible. Again I make a plea to the Government. I have been saying this for the past seven years and other people, perhaps wiser than I am, have said it before me, including one of the Labor Party's own more gifted people, Rex Connor. It is inevitable logic that this country should have a link which will bring the North West Shelf gas to the eastern States--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because we will need that gas before we are through, Senator Walsh. The predictions of the Department of Resources and Energy-and I spoke to its annual report only yesterday-show that there will be a very significant drop off, back to about 42 or 43 per cent, in our sources of supply for petroleum and other fuels from indigenous resources by 1992. That is not very far away when one thinks of lead times for these sorts of things. Yet Senator Walsh asks me why. If he cannot work out why for himself, it is about time he did a little bit of homework and reading. He should read the annual report of the Department of Resources and Energy and then he will see why. It will be necessary for us eventually in this country, unless we find another major oil field-and the computer enhanced pictures that I have seen at the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation show that there does not appear to be another major off-shore oil field-we will need to be able to provide liquid fuel through the conversion of natural gas to methanol or petrol, as is done in New Zealand. The whole of the Maui gas field in New Zealand has been dedicated to that purpose. If we do not have the vision to realise that when our liquid fuel runs out we will not be able to get it automatically from elsewhere, where will we be? We are more dependent on liquid fuel than any other Western society. We do not have the railway lines and canal systems of Europe. This is one of the rationalisations for a link which would bring the North West Shelf gas to the eastern States. I am not a dog in the manger; I am not saying that some of it should not go overseas. We should not sit on that huge reserve ourselves and it is not necessary for us to do so, but it is reasonable that Australia should have the first priority of benefit from that gas in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: We need employment; we need another Snowy Mountains project in this country. Something like that is desperately needed and we can afford it if it is a genuine investment in our future. I have no complaints about deficits, provided the money is being invested in something that will produce jobs and income and do something for this country in the future. We should not mess around with stupid little schemes like the community employment program, which everybody knows are a complete disaster and a waste of money. Those young people should be put to work on a project like a gas line across the country. That is something which would appeal to their sense of patriotism; it is something that would appeal to their sense of doing something for this country. If we give them such a project they will work. If we do not, what can we expect of them? I say to the Government: This is a project which should be looked at.

The steel towns-Newcastle and Wollongong-are in a depressed state now because no government in this country in recent years has had the guts to bring forward major schemes of development. Is it a fact that we do not need such things? Of course we need them. We need more water storage in this country. We need a broad approach; we need somebody to think big instead of thinking in petty terms all the time. The gas pipeline and the tubes it would need and other equipment that would need to be pushed through very difficult country-a huge task, I agree-would bring our steel towns back to life. There again there would be a multiplier effect. Instead of people going on the dole, they would be paying tax.

I took to heart the comment by Senator Sir John Carrick that I was not interested in pipelines. Perhaps I spoke a little more about pipelines today than I would have done because I wanted to convince him that, among other things, I am very interested in pipelines. I am very interested in anything that makes this country better, develops it and provides something better and more productive for the generations to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak for very long, but I wish to make a couple of comments on the reasons that have been given by the Opposition for opposing the Pipeline Authority Amendment Bill 1985. This renegotiation provides for full cost recovery by the year 2006 by the Authority and for compression stations to be constructed as necessary. In that renegotiated agreement the construction of the spur to Orange, Bathurst and Lithgow is also provided. That is a significant achievement because had that haulage agreement not been renegotiated or some equivalent action taken, depending upon the discount rate assumed and the rate of inflation and so on, in 2006 dollars, within a reasonable range of probability for discount rates and inflation, the Authority would have been left with a deficit of something between $1 billion and $2 billion. It was very important, therefore, that the agreement be renegotiated and Senator Gareth Evans should be commended for having organised that renegotiation with a company which has not always been easy to deal with in the past, as I am sure Senator Sir John Carrick would know.
—I certainly acknowledge that.

—Yes. The reasons given by the Opposition for opposing the Bill include its doubts about AGL having a member on the Pipeline Authority. Prima facie I think that is a reasonable objection on the ground that there may be seen to be some conflict of interest. However, the major issue on which the conflict of interest question could arise is the renegotiation of the agreement and that has already been done. Although it is fair enough to acknowledge that, I think the risk is slight. The Opposition's second objection is that the legislation removes the requirement for parliamentary scrutiny of pipeline spurs and other major capital works. That would have been a reasonable proposition if it had come from an opposition or a political group which had consistently applied the principle of accountability to Parliament for the expenditure or availability of public moneys. The present Opposition, the Liberal Party of Australia, however, has no such record of having consistently applied that principle.

SPEECH.PARA: I need go back only to 1979 when the present Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Howard) and then Treasurer stitched up an arrangement-a bit of cosmetic accounting-with Telecom Australia under which a total of some $600m was loaned back, to use the euphemism used by the Treasurer of the day, to Telecom in order to reduce Telecom's borrowing requirement for capital works and therefore achieve a consequential cosmetic reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement. That loan back arrangement was never approved by Parliament. No interest was payable by Telecom on the loan back until this Government came into office and corrected that in the 1984 Budget. In other words, the present Leader of the Liberal Party, who was then the Treasurer, presumably with the knowledge of his Cabinet colleagues and the rest of the parliamentary Liberal Party of the day, had no qualms at all about handing over to Telecom $600m free of interest, with no obligation to repay and no requirement for parliamentary approval. It was never endorsed by Parliament. I find it somewhat distressing that a political party with that sort of record could come in here and sermonise about the need for accountability by Parliament and parliamentary scrutiny of the expenditure of public money.

I gather from Senator Mason's comments and from what other people have told me that the Australian Democrats will support the legislation, and I thank them for that. Therefore, the Bill will be passed. I endorse Senator Mason's comment about the Bathurst-Orange-Lithgow spur; something which has been on the agenda for a very long time and something which is likely to be achieved-I think it could be said to be guaranteed-in the not too distant future.

SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985
Mr President, this is the last Bill in this series of 11 Bills.

This Bill will amend several sales tax statutes to make a number of technical changes and correct certain drafting errors that have been identified in connection with anti-avoidance amendments of the sales tax law enacted earlier this year. In this area, the amendments proposed by this Bill are, without exception, not substantive in nature.

The Bill will also make consequential changes to the Sales Tax Regulations to ``mirror'' changes, associated with the imposition of tax at the 10 per cent rate on biscuits and ice cream products, that are to be made by the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1985.

As I mentioned earlier, Mr President, when introducing the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1985, this Bill contains an anti-avoidance provision that will strike down last minute transactions carried out by persons in an attempt to avoid a liability for sales tax that would arise out of the amendments of the sales tax laws being made by these Bills.
Mr President, the explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable senators also contains detailed explanations of the technical aspects of this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX (Nos. 1-4 AND 6-9) AMENDMENT BILLS 1985
SALES TAX (No. 5) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

Under the present structure of the Sales Tax Legislation, each of the Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos. 1-9) has a complementary Taxing Act. These Taxing Acts impose the Sales Tax and prescribe the rates of tax payable in respect of goods. The rate depends on the particular schedule, if any, of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, that the goods may be listed in.
These nine Bills will amend the Sales Tax Acts to rationalise the wholesale sales tax rate structure by reducing the number of rate categories from four to three. The specific changes are as follows.

Goods that continue to be covered by the second schedule of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act will, under these Bills, be subject to tax at the new rate of 30 per cent. As I mentioned in my second reading speech on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill goods including jewellery, furs, cosmetics and certain electronic equipment will be in this category.
At the same time, the Bills will increase the rate of tax payable on goods covered by the third schedule to that act from 7.5 per cent to 10 per cent.

Finally, Mr President, the Bills will re-impose tax at the existing rates on goods covered by the fourth, fifth and sixth schedules to that Act, as well as goods that are subject to tax at the general rate.
Details of these Bills are also set out in the explanatory memorandum that is being circulated to senators.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.
SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

Mr President, on 19 September 1985 the Treasurer announced a number of significant initiatives, as part of the Government's tax reform package, that will rationalise the structure and broaden the scope of the present wholesale sales tax system.
This is the main Bill in a series of 11 Bills that will amend the sales tax law to give effect to those rationalisation and base broadening measures.
At this stage, Mr President, it would perhaps be useful to honourable senators if I were to outline briefly the changes to be made by these Bills.

First, the wholesale sales tax base is to be broadened, principally with the intention of reducing anomalies by subjecting to tax certain goods that are presently exempt. Secondly, the rate of sales tax payable on records and sound and video tapes, a number of household and personal care items and certain other goods is to be substantially reduced. Finally, several classification anomalies and inconsistencies that presently exist in the sales tax law are to be rectified.
The Bills will also effect some rationalisation in the present multiple rate structure of the wholesale sales tax by reducing from four to three the number of rates that apply to various goods.
The Bills will also give effect to the Government's decision, announced in the 1985-86 Budget speech, to provide an exemption from sales tax for horses imported into Australia after 20 August 1985.
The opportunity is also being taken to make several technical changes and to correct certain drafting errors associated with amendments of the sales tax law enacted earlier this year.
Taken together, these measures are estimated to produce a net revenue gain in 1985-86 of $75 million and $110 million in a full year.
I turn now to discuss in detail the changes to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act proposed by this Bill.
Base Broadening Measures

The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, Mr President, is a key element in the legislative structure of the wholesale sales tax. Its first schedule describes all classes of goods that are exempt from the tax. It also contains five further schedules that specify goods or classes of goods that are taxable at the rates specified in the sales tax Acts. Goods that are not described in any of those six schedules are taxable at the general rate of tax. That rate is presently 20 per cent.
Confectionery is presently taxable at the 20 per cent general rate. This Bill will specifically include confectionery in the third schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act.

The effect of this, Mr President, together with certain changes to the Rates Acts that I propose to introduce shortly, will be to reduce the rate of tax payable on confectionery items from 20 per cent to 10 per cent.

There is, however, a wide range of goods that are non-staple food items and close substitutes for taxable confectionery that is presently exempt from Sales Tax. These goods, that might generically be described as snack foods, include potato crisps, nuts, ice creams, flavoured ice blocks and most biscuits. These goods are often used in substitution for confectionery and compete for sales in the market place with it.

In order to remove inequities in taxation treatment between confectionery and snack foods, the Government has decided to bring snack foods within the sales tax base. The effect of these measures will be to tax these goods at the 10 per cent rate, on and from 20 September 1985.
I turn now to the other base broadening measures in this Bill.

Goods that are ordinarily used for household purposes are presently subject to tax at the rate of 7.5 per cent. Examples of these goods, that are included in the third schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act, are refrigerators, washing machines and portable cooking appliances.

There are, however, a number of other similar goods such as domestic stoves and ranges and water heating and storage equipment that are specifically exempt from sales tax by reason of their inclusion in the first schedule of that Act.

This Bill will bring the sales tax treatment of all these household goods into line by incorporating them in the existing third schedule. Mr President, I will shortly introduce further Bills to set the rate of tax for goods in this schedule at 10 per cent.

Various goods presently exempt from sales tax will, by virtue of the changes proposed in this Bill, also become taxable at the proposed rate of 10 per cent by reason of their inclusion in the third schedule. These include wrapping materials, bags and fastening materials for domestic or household use, water filtering and sterilizing equipment and books of maps.
High Rate Goods
The second schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act specifies goods that are presently taxable at the highest rate of 32.5 per cent.

Many of the goods covered by the second schedule are everyday household or personal care items. Other goods in that schedule, such as totalizators, are more akin to computers that are taxable at the lower 20 per cent rate.
Consistent with the Government's broad objective of rationalising the wholesale sales tax system, this Bill will remove a range of these goods from the second schedule.
As the goods to be omitted will no longer be specified in any schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act they will generally fall to be taxed at the lower rate of 20 per cent.

Some goods will, however, remain in the second schedule and fall to be taxed at the rate of 30 per cent-a reduction of 2.5 percentage points. Among the goods that will in future be taxed at the 30 per cent rate are jewellery, furs and fur garments, cosmetics, television and radio receivers, video recorders, photographic equipment, watches, clocks and gambling and amusement machines.
Anomalies and Inconsistencies

The need to specify in the law and in some detail the various goods and classes of goods that are subject to sales tax at differing rates has led to anomalies arising from time to time as new and changed products come onto the market. Unless corrected, the existence of such anomalies involves particular goods, etc. being taxed at higher rates than broadly comparable products or close substitutes. For example, while tea as ordinarily understood is exempt from sales tax, herbal teas are taxable.
Anomalies of this kind have, by governments past and present, regularly been addressed by amending legislation.

In yet other cases, goods which ought in logic to be taxable are exempt, often because of drafting defects or oversights in specifying the category of goods to be exempt or taxable. For example, ships and vessels designed for use for private purposes such as pleasure or recreation are generally taxable. If however, a ship or vessel is purchased to be used for private transport or accommodation, it is exempt from tax.
The Bill will correct these and a number of other anomalies, details of which are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
Imported Horses

As part of the Government's 1985-86 Budget, the Treasurer announced several measures to assist the Australian horse racing industry. This Bill will give effect to the decision to exempt from sales tax horses imported into Australia after 20 August 1985.

Finally, Mr President, I refer to the Government's decision to exempt from sales tax earth stations, designed to receive the household and community broadcasting satellite services, that was announced when this Bill was introduced in another place. That exemption will apply on and from 20 September 1985. This proposal is not contained in the Bill. However, the Government proposes to move an amendment during the committee stage of debate on the Bill to give effect to its decision to exempt these earth stations. At that time, the opportunity will also be taken to effect some minor changes to correct deficiencies that have been identified since the introduction of the Bill in the other place.
Anti-Avoidance Provisions
The amendments of the Sales Tax Law that I have just outlined for honourable senators will have effect from midnight on 19 September 1985.

Sadly, Mr President, there are still those in the community who, between the time when these measures were announced by the Treasurer on 19 September and midnight of that day, may have entered into transactions in order to avoid sales tax liabilities resulting from classification and rate changes which would clearly arise after that time.

Against that possibility, I mention that anti-avoidance provisions designed to protect the revenue from such last minute transactions are included in the Sales Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1985 which I will introduce shortly.

Mr President, an explanatory memorandum containing detailed explanations of technical aspects of the Bill is being circulated to honourable senators. I do not, therefore, propose to further address the matters covered by this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
